field_edited_text.value:
Another plaza was recommended in the area of
the public market and pedestrian ways would
link the two plazas as well as other parts of the
core. A traffic loop system was suggested to
eliminate or reduce congestion combined with a
one-way street system in and adjacent to the
core. The provision of space for public agencies
serving the area was also recommended.

3. Staging Possibilities

A suggested program for staging the
recommended improvements was presented in
graphic form for each study area. Priorities
were selected on the basis of improvements:

That were primarily rehabilitation

That resulted in maximum improvement with
minimum disruption of existing buildings

That resulted in objectives being more easily
attained

That cost less in relationship to the benefits
gained

That provided maximum benefit to existing
businesses

That could be carried out without federal urban
renewal aid and with relatively low financial aid
from the city

That required a minimum financial
commitment of property owners.

4. Cost Elements

It was considered unrealistic to prepare detailed
cost estimates for improvements in each area
because of the large number of unknown
factors. As guidelines, however, unit costs were
estimated which would enable involved groups
to prepare cost estimates of proposed
Improvements.

Unit costs were given for new construction,
including apartments, office buildings, retail
buildings, parking lot development, street and
sidewalk improvements, construction of
pedestrian malls and landscaping.

5. Design Considerations

An important aspect of the study was the
development of design themes for the three
study areas to indicate factors that should be
considered in any improvement programs and
to show by graphic illustration some examples
of the effects of good design treatment.

A variety of techniques was used which could
be applied to any one of the three areas.
Examples of blockfront treatment, showing
before and after effects, were shown to
demonstrate that the visual image of an area
could be changed considerably with little effort
or expense. Also illustrated was a variety of
designs for street furniture such as light
standards, directional signs, seating and
fountains.

29

Illustrative plans for showing possible treatment
of plaza areas were included to demonstrate the
wide range of possibilities even in limited or
confined areas.

6. Utilization of Urban Renewal

Factors to be considered if urban renewal
projects were utilized to carry out the planning
proposals for the three study areas were
examined. They included the eligibility of
possible project areas, costs, extent and
proposed use of land to be made available for
new development, and relocation requirements.

The review did not attempt to determine
whether urban renewal should or should not be
used but was intended to outline the scope and
extent of work and expense connected with
large-scale renewal programs.

Suggested boundaries for urban renewal project
areas were described within the three areas. A
review of survey data indicated that the three
areas were eligible for urban renewal assistance
in terms of blight and environmental
deficiencies. Estimates were made of relocation
requirements in each area. Cost estimates
ranged from $2.6 million for a minimum area in
the Monument Street area to $14 million for
part of the Pennsylvania Avenue area. Costs
were broken down to show gross and net
project costs and the estimated local and
federal shares, based on a 25% local
contribution.
